abstractText: Processing chaotic signals is a complicated task due to their nonlinear and non-periodical properties. Conventional linear filters do not allow to properly denoise signals generated by chaotic systems, distorting the carrier while removing the noise, which is critical for such applications as coherent chaotic communications. In this paper, we propose a novel denoising algorithm, called Ensemble Intrinsic TimeScale Decomposition (EITD) using specific chaotic noise generators. We may use specific chaotic noise generators in the known Ensemble Empirical Mode Decomposition (EEMD), as we also show. Considering the examples of Rössler and Lorenz systems as chaotic waveforms generators, we compare the developed algorithm modifications with other filtration algorithms using ITD and EMD. We use the root-mean-square error (RMSE) as a metric to estimate the denoising quality. Signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) range −10...20 dB is examined, and white, pink and chaotic noise generators are utilized to disturb signals under study. As a result, we explicitly show that the developed approach provides the error 2-10 times less in the case of white and pink noise, and is capable of denoising chaotic signals in case of all the considered types of noises, in contrast to Conventional and Iterative ITD and EMD algorithms. INDEX TERMS chaotic signals, digital signal processing, empirical mode decomposition, intrinsic timescale decomposition, denoising, and non-linear filtering.

INDEX TERMS chaotic signals, digital signal processing, empirical mode decomposition, intrinsic timescale decomposition, denoising, and non-linear filtering.
I. INTRODUCTION
IN recent decades, chaotic signals have been widely usedin the various scientific fields such as chaotic communication [1]–[4], cryptography [5], radars [6], sonars [7], various sensors [8] etc. This type of non-periodic signal often possesses a non-stationarity and broadband spectrum. One of the unique properties of chaotic signals is non-repeatability, which significantly complicates their processing. Coherent chaotic communication systems are especially noise-suffered [9], and the development of denoising algorithms [10] is relevant for this scientific area. Since chaotic signals demonstrate a noise-like behavior, linear filters are no longer useful for this task. Therefore, denoising chaotic time series or extracting chaotic time series from a mixture with a noise
component becomes a major problem. The performance of any denoising algorithm depends on the amount of information about the signal available. Many approaches are proposed to reduce or clean the noise present in this class of non-linear signals. In [11], [12], an original discrete-time Kalman filtering implementation is proposed to estimate the states of chaotic signals with white noise. Kalman filtering is a state-space estimator that provides recursive minimum mean-squared error estimates for linear systems embedded in Gaussian noise. The latter cannot be used directly to estimate non-linear state space models. Therefore, an approximate solution is required which allows the extension of the Kalman filtering framework to nonlinear state-space models, as is done in the referred studies. Another class

of suitable filtration techniques utilizes empirical mode decomposition (EMD). Denoising algorithms based on EMD [13], [14] are widely used in many applications: medicine, seismology, hydroacoustics, radio monitoring, etc. [15]–[18]. Our research team presents new denoising algorithms based on ITD [19] in the context of chaotic signal processing. We study the proposed algorithms on a set of test chaotic signals noised with various noise generators, including chaotic ones, and compare denoising results with other algorithms based on EMD. The novelty and contribution of the paper are as follows:
• we applied our recently developed denoising algorithms based on ITD (Ensemble ITD, Conventional ITD and Iterative ITD) to a new class of complicated non-linear signals, namely, chaotic signals, and explored the possibility of their filtering from standard types of noise (white and pink); • in addition, we investigate the possibility of denoising chaotic signals from sources of chaotic noise.
The rest of the paper is organized as follows. In Section II, we consider the concept of decomposition into internal timescale components. Section III describes filtering algorithms based on this concept. In Section IV, we consider chaotic signals and noise generators under study. Section V describes the results obtained. Section VI concludes the paper.

DENOISING SIGNALS USING ITD Based on the solutions for filtering signals from noise using EMD [13]–[16] (Ensemble EMD – EEMD [17], Conventional EMD – CEMD [18], [21] and Iterative EMD – IEMD [18]), the research team developed new algorithms for filtering signals from noise Ensemble ITD – EITD, Conventional ITD – CITD and Iterative ITD – IITD [19]. Below we will give a brief mathematical description of them. A thorough comparison with other methodologies, including wavelet analysis, was given in [22].
A. ENSEMBLE ITD (EITD) Idea. The algorithm consists in sifting an ensemble of signals with the addition of additive white Gaussian noise. The average value for the ensemble of implementations of each EM is considered a solution. Since EITD is a TFE analysis method, the added white noise is averaged with a sufficient number of implementations; the only constant part that withstands the averaging process is the true useful signal. With the help of an ensemble mean, it is possible to naturally divide the scales without any a priori choice of a subjective criterion. This new approach takes full advantage of the statistical characteristics of white noise to distort the signal in its true neighborhood of the solution and to cancel it after completing the task. EITD is a significant improvement over the original ITD and is a method of data analysis using noise: noise-assisted data analysis (NADA).

B. CONVENTIONAL ITD (CITD) The main idea of the method is as follows. Initially, the attempt to use ITD as a noise reduction tool arose from the need to know whether a particular mode contains useful
information or is noise. Thus, the procedures for checking the significance of EM were developed on the basis of statistical analysis of EM obtained as a result of the decomposition of signals consisting of white Gaussian noise. The concept underlying the above significance verification procedure is quite simple and at the same time convincing. If the energy of EM noise is known, then in reality, if the signal contains both useful information and noise, a significant discrepancy between the energy of EM noise and the energy of the corresponding EM mixture of noise and useful signal indicates the presence of useful information. In the noise reduction problem, this causes the signal to be restored using only those EM that contain useful information and discarding those EM that carry mainly noise (modes that share the same amount of energy with the corresponding case only for noise).
In practice, pure noise is never available for applying ITD and estimating EM energies, so the usefulness of the abovementioned method depends on whether it is possible to estimate the energy of pure noise modes directly based on the actual noisy signal. The latter usually takes place due to the characteristic feature of ITD. In addition to the first purely noise EM, the power spectra of other EM exhibit self-similar characteristics similar to those that manifest themselves in any structure of the dyadic filter bank. As a result, the EM energies Ep should decrease linearly on a semi-logarithmic diagram, for example, log2Ep relative to p. It also turns out that the first EM carries a large amount of energy.
We will consider white Gaussian noise.

C. ITERATIVE ITD (IITD) The direct application of threshold processing of EM values like noise reduction using wavelet coefficients is impossible and can have disastrous consequences in terms of the continuity of the restored signal. This arises as a result of the special attributes possessed by EM, namely, they resemble a sinusoid with AM/FM modulation with a zero mean value. As a result, this ensures that even in the absence of noise, in any interval χ(i)j = [χ (i) j , ..., χ (i) j+1], the absolute value of the

EM with the number i, i = 1, 2, ..., N will be below any nonzero threshold near the intersection points of zero χ(i)j and χ (i) j+1. In other words, based on the absolute amplitude of isolated EM, it is impossible to conclude whether they correspond to noise or a useful signal. However, we can guess whether the interval χ(i)j is dominant by noise or dominant by a signal based on a single extremum c(i)(r(i)j ), which corresponds to this interval. If there is no signal, the absolute value of this extreme will be below the threshold value. Alternatively, if there is a strong signal, the extreme value is expected to exceed the threshold value. Moreover, since noise and signal have the same bandwidth in each EM, signal dominance is highly likely to be extended to all EM samples related to a certain interval between zero crossings.
Based on shift-invariant threshold processing of wavelet coefficients, in which several versions of the signal under consideration with remote noise are iteratively obtained in order to increase noise resistance by averaging, it is possible to develop an ITD-based noise reduction method that uses a similar principle. Note once again that the direct application of shift-invariant noise reduction does not work in the case of ITD. In the case of ITD, the main processing components, the extremes, depend on the signal, which leads to fixed relative positions of the extremes with respect to the signal when the latter is shifted. As a result, the ITD of the shifted versions of the noisy signal corresponds to the ITD of the corresponding ones shifted by the same amount. Therefore, noise averaging cannot be achieved in this way.
Different versions of the signal with remote noise in the case of ITD can only be constructed from different versions of EM after threshold processing. Inevitably, this is only possible by decomposing various noisy versions of the signal itself. Thus, the problem in question boils down to the following question: how, having a signal hidden in the noise, you can create various noisy versions of the actual signal without noise. The answer stems from the ITD concept using the characteristics of the first EM. It is known that in the conditions of white Gaussian noise, the first EM is mainly noise. By circularly shifting a random number of samples of the first IMF, and then adding the resulting noise signal to the sum of the remaining IMF, we get another noisy version of the original signal. In fact, if the first EM consists only of noise, then the total noise variance of the newly generated noise signal coincides with the initial value.

We have considered Rössler and Lorenz systems as they are classical examples of chaotic oscillators used in chaotic communications from the pioneering works on the subject [23] till the recent works [24], [25].
B. NOISE GENERATORS In this paper, we consider the following noise generators:
1) Gaussian white noise; 2) Pink noise; 3) Rössler system; 4) Lorenz system. The noise generator based on the Rössler system has the following set of parameters a = 0.1, b = 0.1, c = 14. Since we are considering an interfering signal, it should be very different from the filtered signal by some criterion. As such an estimate, we can apply the quantitative return map analysis (QRMA) proposed in [26].
Simulation parameters are as follows: integration step h = 0.01, simulation time T = 1000 sec. According to this criterion, the signal of the Rössler system with parameters a = 0.1, b = 0.1, c = 14 differs by 100% from the denoised signal (see Figure 2).
The noise generator based on the Lorentz system has the parameters indicated in 18.
Again, these types of oscillators were chosen because of their prevalence in the field of chaotic communication. The admixture of a chaotic oscillator as noise to the signal of another chaotic oscillator can be considered crosstalk, which is relevant for the open transmission of chaotic messages through media in radio or acoustic communications.

sections.heading: V. EXPERIMENTAL RESULTS
sections.text:
Experimental results are presented in the figures below.
Figure 3 shows the signal of Rössler system state variable X and its admixture with different noise generators: white noise, pink noise, another Rössler chaotic generator, and Lorenz chaotic generator. All noises were normalized to achieve the same SNR -10 dB.
Figure 4 illustrates the performance of the denoising algorithms based on EMD and ITD. The Lorenz chaotic signal is considered as an example at SNR = -10 dB and white noise as a disturbance. The black line shows the original chaotic waveform. One may see that EEMD and EITD restore the signal most accurately, with slight high-frequency noise left. Results by CEMD are much more inaccurate, but still an original waveform is recognizable. Other algorithms – IEMD, CITD, IITD – show low performance and are practically inapplicable for the task.
Analysis of the algorithms’ performance at different SNR levels is presented in Figures 5 and 6. In the case of white and pink noise EEMD and EITD both show the best accuracy, 2- 10 times better than other considered algorithms, with the exponential decay of error as SNR linearly increases. In the case of Rössler noise generator, all algorithms except ensemble ones (EEMD and EITD) show an inability to appropriately perform the denoising task. In the case of the Lorenz noise generator, iterative algorithms (IITD and IEMD) provide insufficient results, other methods are approximately equal. According to the results, we may range the methods in the following order:
1) EITD: most accurate and fast; 2) EEMD: also accurate, but computationally less effi-
cient [19]; 3) CITD: shows the second denoising accuracy; 4) CEMD, IITD, IEMD: less accurate or even inapplica-
ble in most cases. The same performance test was conducted for the Lorenz system. The list above is generally applicable to the achieved results.
Note that root-mean-square error (RMSE) between original and denoised signal is given in Figures in absolute values.
There is an important remark that all algorithms based on EMD and ITD have many parameters, but in this paper,

Parameter optimization was not the aim of this work, but with another set of parameters, one could probably achieve better results for outsider methods. However, this does not diminish the positive qualities of the developed algorithm, which works well with default parameters.
VI. CONCLUSION In this paper, we propose a novel denoising algorithm, EITD, in the application of chaotic signals denoising, and compare it with EMD and ITD-based denoising algorithms. We experimentally found that EITD gives more preferable results in most cases. The quality of noise reduction with the use of EITD is also superior and 2-10 times higher for white and pink noise than when applying other methods. Considering the Lorenz system, SNR = 0 dB and white noise, the normalized RMSE of the denoised signal would be 25% by EITD and EEMD, 75% by CITD, 120% by CEMD, and even higher by IEMD and IITD. The explanation lies in the fact that the noise is averaged in it, no matter what generator of noise – white, pink, Rössler or Lorenz is used; thus, it decomposes the signal into more stable components, and also works faster [19]. Compared with our method, EEMD also performs denoising at a high accuracy level but is not computationally efficient. CITD also demonstrated acceptable denoising efficiency. CEMD, IITD, and IEMD do not always work correctly, but we suppose that there is a possibility to improve their performance by adjusting the parameters.
The application of the proposed algorithms will help to improve coherent chaotic communication systems in terms of increasing the resistance to noise in the channel, which is a complicated task due to the noise-like spectrum of chaotic signals. With the developed algorithms, the transmitted chaotic signal will be closer to the original chaotic waveform, which will improve the quality of synchronization between two chaotic oscillators, resulting in a lower bit error rate. Implementation of ITD in the coherent chaotic communication system is the aim of our further research. Other application fields will also be considered.

Voznesensky et al.: Denoising Chaotic Signals using Intrinsic Timescale Decomposition
ALEXANDER VOZNESENSKY was born in Saint Petersburg, Russia, in 1991. He received his B.S. and M.S. degrees in applied mathematics and informatics from Saint Petersburg Electrotechnical University "LETI", in 2012 and 2014, respectively, and he currently works on the Ph.D. thesis. Since 2012, he has been a Data Scientist with the Department of Automation and Control Processes, Faculty of Computer Science and Technology, Saint Petersburg Electrotechnical Univer-
sity "LETI". He is the author of more than 50 articles and three patents. His research interests include MATLAB, mathematical modeling, signal processing, image processing, video processing, neural networks, CNN, C/C++, CUDA, parallel computing, data mining, data science, and data analysis.
DENIS BUTUSOV is a Professor of ComputerAided Engineering at the St. Petersburg Electrotechnical University, Russia, where he is also a Head of Youth Research Institute. He has published extensively in nonlinear systems simulation, specifically numerical methods, geometrical integration, memristive circuits, discrete chaotic maps, and a wide variety of applications, including chaotic sensors, nonlinear systems identification, power systems, and chaos-based cryptography. Dr.
Butusov and his collaborators are the authors of the controllable symmetry concept in numerical simulations of nonlinear systems. He has been an IEEE Member (IEEE Council on Electronic Design Automation) since 2014. He serves as Associate Editor for the Journal of Control, Automation and Electrical Systems
TIMUR KARIMOV is an Associate Professor of Computer-Aided Engineering at the St. Petersburg Electrotechnical University, Russia, where he is also a Researcher in Youth Research Institute. He received his Ph.D. degree in 2018. He has published in chaos-based communication systems, nonlinear systems simulation, nonlinear systems identification, numerical integration methods, and other related topics. Dr. Karimov and his collaborators have extensive contributions to sensors
based on chaotic oscillators.
VYACHESLAV RYBIN received the M.S. degree in computer technology engineering from Saint Petersburg Electrotechnical University "LETI", in 2019, and he currently works on the Ph.D. thesis. Since 2017, he has been an Assistant Professor at the Department of Computer-Aided Design, Faculty of Computer Science and Technology, Saint Petersburg Electrotechnical University "LETI". His research interests include system simulation in MATLAB and LabVIEW environments, chaos
theory, chaotic communication systems, nonlinear dynamics and analog and digital electronics.
DMITRII KAPLUN received the Ph.D. degree in 2009 at Saint Petersburg Electrotechnical University "LETI", Russia, with the thesis in digital signal processing. In 2015, he became an Associate Professor of Saint Petersburg Electrotechnical University. Currently, he is a Senior Researcher at the same university. His research and academic work are concerned with digital filter banks, radio monitoring and hydroacoustic monitoring applications, filter bank implementation using FPGA
and GPU, MATLAB, digital filtering, distributed arithmetic, reconfigurable systems, computer vision, and machine learning. He regularly takes part in different joint projects connected to hydroacoustic and radio signal processing, vibrational signal processing and analysis, and software-hardware implementation of digital signal processing algorithms in radio monitoring and hydroacoustic monitoring applications. He achieved the most substantial results in the fields of digital filtering, reconfigurable systems, digital filter bank design, radio monitoring, and hydroacoustic monitoring system design. He is the author of more than 70 articles on digital signal processing, digital image and video processing, and embedded systems. Dr. Kaplun was awarded special prizes by the Ministry of Education and Science of the Russian Federation for his academic results.
ERIVELTON NEPOMUCENO received his B.Eng. and Ph.D. degrees in Electrical Engineering from the University of São João del-Rei (UFSJ, 2001) and the Federal University of Minas Gerais (UFMG, 2005), respectively. He was an Associate Professor at the Federal University of São João del-Rei until 2021, when he was appointed as Assistant Professor at the Center for Ocean Energy Research and Department of Electronic Engineering at Maynooth University. He
was a visiting Research Fellow at the Technological Institute of Aeronautics in Brazil (2005), Imperial College London (2013/14), Saint Petersburg Electrotechnical University in Russia (2019), and at City, University of London (2020/21). Dr. Nepomuceno is a Senior Member of IEEE and elected Secretary of the IEEE Technical Committee on Nonlinear Circuits and Systems. He has been elected coordinator of the Technical Committee on System Identification and Data Science for the Brazilian Association of Automatic Control. He is Deputy EiC of IEEE Latin America Transactions, and he serves as Associate Editor for IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems II: Express Briefs, Journal of Control, Automation and Electrical Systems, and Mathematical Problems in Engineering. His research interests include analysis, modeling, and control of circuits, systems and networks, computer arithmetic, system identification, intelligent systems, chaos, and cryptography.
